Reiteration/clarification of my prior post:

The server needs to know what the client meant in making request  in order 
to claim that the request succeeded (200 OK).

Either the meaning of a POST is constrained by the request-entity and the 
requested URI or it is constrained by the request-entity and the 
content-type of the resource identified by that URI.

If you believe the former, then you believe the client cannot make a POST 
request without some out of band communication with the server and perhaps 
we should rename the POST method to DO_SOMETHING_WITH_THIS_REQUEST_ENTITY. 
If you believe the former then you should acknowledge that POST has no 
public definition at all (the intro to section 9 of rfc2616, 
notwithstanding) and that you really don't need a generic method name at 
all because the semantics are private between the client and server in any 
case (that you should really use a private method name).

However, if you insist on using POST as your method name, you MUST think 
that POST has a public meaning and therefore that clients can make a POST 
request without an out-of-band communication with a server operator.  I 
think the only way to constrain the meaning enough for the server to 
understand the client's intentions is via content-type.  If you can think 
of another constraint, please say so.

If you cannot provide another constraint, then you must conclude that 
content-type is the only way to constrain meaning, that the client must 
understand the content-type of the resource in order to POST to it, that 
therefore HTTP is about transferring the resource-model via content-type 
(the MoST thesis is correct), and that the server may NOT arbitrarily 
reinterpret the meaning of HTTP methods in a way that is visible to the 
client (the REST thesis is either vague or wrong).

QED
